name: Death attack is dead(ish), long live crippling strike?
author: EasternPromises

posts.author: EasternPromises
posts.content:
With the changes EE made to death attack i.e. you only get one, does crippling strike become appealing?

Or even without the changes, how do you feel crippling strike rates in terms of power? I have been playing around with numerous epic dodgers using primarily rogue and crippling strike seems to make fighting living targets laughable.

Thoughts?

posts.author: Mirnaia
posts.content:
I still play 1.69 :)
I'm not decided on crippling strike - don't get me wrong, it's awesome when it works, but I think you have to ask two questions immediately. This is for solo, if you're in a party, things are different.
One is, it's a bit of a "win more" button. If you can SA them, you can very likely beat them.
Two, what method(s) does the build in question use to generate SA's? If your opponent can't fight back, reducing Str isn't as great as it looks on paper.

That said, emotionally speaking, I love crippling strike, and also, if you're taking many rogue levels, the useful bonus feats run out very quickly, so you might as well take it.
And a real question, which not even the wiki seems to answer: how long does it last? Same as called shot?

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
I think it last 6 rounds same as the other de-buffs (taunt, called-shot, etc).
For maximum effectiveness on CS you need ITWF on a martial-rogue with 7 attacks, thus reducing an opponent's return strikes by 6AB after your first salvo.
Once upon a time when I was putting myself in ridiculous challenges, decided on taking upon Robilar (level 35+ fighter/cot/wm with Dev Crit on WoG) with guys that don't have it, one of them was my commando-rogue and I clicked fast, unleashed an opening salvo of three attacks, all crippling-strikes, reduced his AB by 6, then my ED protected me from dying to his opening Dev Strike his next attacks were just barely below my AC and then he was mine. Boy that was tough, the adrenaline was pumping through my blood as I watched the combat-log & stayed on top of him till finally, I took him out & sent him to meet his ancestors... Yes, I do believe that was CS that allowed me to do that & snatch that sweet victory off of him.

So, is it worth it?
Absolutely.

posts.author: Mirnaia
posts.content:
Sweet story, Val! Robilar is a really iconic boss in WoG, and it makes a very nice pro-crippling strike argument. (The one character I fought him with was a zen archer cleric, so called shot + dc48 implosions took care of him. This was at a time when storm of vengeance was bugged and wouldn't go off.) Robilar is a great example because most likely you won't be able to knock him off his feet.

It's kind of like a mini Bigby 5 in a pinch except it also reduces incoming damage. Also, Called Shot lasts only 4 rounds, not 6, and each instance has its own timer, not the entire stack.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Crippling the Death attack certainly tilts the scales in favor of rogue.
Crippling strike is an old and well known combat move. It definitely can win a fight. But to compare it with Death attack, at least to me is like comparing KD with Taunt. They are just too different.
So is Assassin still worth it?
You still have Death attack. But only one paralyzation attempt per flurry. That means that characters with ED are as good as immune to the paralyzation. And monks can dodge ranged paralyzation attempts in a similar way.
There are still reasons to choose assassin. You still get Death attacks, even if they are nerfed. It also offers a way to get "sneak attacks" without an xp penalty.  You still have the undispellable Improved invisibility.  And you have Great dexterity as an epic bonus feat, so you can build with Great dexterity X and achieve 40 dex if you are so inclined.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Wait, I believe there is something amiss here.

To threaten a Paralysing Death Attack, the opponent must not be in combat and unaware of the threatened PDA.
A death attack only triggers a paralysis save if the target is not engaged in combat, as per this feat's description.
  • As all attacks in a flurry are effectively simultaneous, there will be a saving throw for each attack in the opening flurry of combat.
  • The difficulty class of the saving throw is 10 + assassin level + intelligence modifier.
  • The duration is 1 turn per assassin level.
  • As of Enhanced Edition patch 1.74, only the first attack in a flurry will trigger a paralysis save.

So does ED and Dodge of a Ranged Attack still work?

That should not be possible, and should not be allowed.

How can you dodge something that you are not aware of?

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
The slippery mind makes more sense in a build with CoT where you have at least O.K. saves to take advantage of that second roll for your Will save.
Otherwise, you would have a second chance with an abysmal rate of success, like in typical rogue builds (without CoT).

Also, you can do slightly better than simply "dance on the head of a pin", maybe even Epic Dodge - On the head of a Pin.
